content:
I do not ever recall there being an email.comcast.net mail server.

Incoming POP accounts use mail.comcast.net but that is for incoming mail not outgoing.

The SMTP server name for comcast is given by them as smtp.comcast.net See https://www.xfinity.com/support/articles/email-client-programs-with-xfinity-email

content:
Last I heard the update rate for existing installations was set to zero. the only ones getting the new version being those that downloaded it.

BTW I have no idea what that image has to do with what you wrote. Did you perhaps post the wrong file?

I do not rely on the computer to make decisions for me, I look at the data and facts myself like this https://github.com/thunderbird/import-export-tools-ng/issues/600 SO the import export tools update is imminent.

this qnote has a similar issue https://github.com/mlazdans/qnote/issues/54 without a response from the author in the whole 19 hour since the issue was raised. You might want to follow that issue as it is raised where it might get a response.

Note++ which qnote purports to expand the feature set of is compatible with V128. Is it some expanded feature you need or an addon that works?

Note there is NO opt-out of Thunderbird update checking.

content:
You have an outlook.com account and a hotmail account, but there are 4 outlook smtp servers. Delete all of them except the ones for the 2 MS accounts, and then make sure your BrianHenryHome account is set to send on the Default smtp (select the account in the left pane of Account Settings, set the smtp in the right pane's Outgoing Server (SMTP) drop-down). Repeat for the hotmail account. The smtp settings for the 2 accounts should be the same except for the User Name (email address).

If you have the current release 115, and the smtp is smtp.office365.com, 587, STARTTLS, you should be able to select OAuth2 in the authentication drop-down, but if not, there is a way to force it:

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1451090#answer-1659631

Check also that the incoming server is outlook.office365.com, 993, SSL/TLS, OAuth2, email address.

content:
I've made some progress now. I didn't have cookies enabled for this account. Enabling them let me get to the next step, where it wanted to use the Passkey that I just set up. That's connected to the fingerprint sensor on my laptop. However, I couldn't get it to prompt me to use the sensor, so I had to select "use another method" (for which I chose confirmation via my phone).

This now works. I've logged out and back in, and it didn't prompt me again.

So the main issue was that I hadn't been allowing cookies.

content: Aw, shucks, ma'am... I was glad to help :) (as an aside, the description field is in the SMTP server setup pane. Both of the had the same description. It's only documentation, but the most common reason for the message your husband received is when a user has one email address on the incoming server settiings and a different on on the SMTP settings. This commonly happens when a person has two or more accounts and gets them crossed. By putting the email account in description field, the likelihood is minimized because the error will be obvious when viewing link to SMTP settings from the account pane. As it is, that wasn't his problem.)
creator: davidsk

content: The simple way to change profiles, assuming both are within the default profiles folder, is to click help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profiles' in left column and selecting 'about:profiles.' Both should appear here and you can switch from one to another. - If the importexporttools' addon is not installed, add it. - now, highlight the desired messages, rightclick and choose to export as EML messages - now, switch to the other profile - highlight the folder to receive the messages - rightclick and select the importexport menu option to import EML messages
creator: davidsk
